State awards $390,000 to Hopkins despite civil suit
By ALLEN SHORT
Maryland state officials have
released from escroe some
$390,000 in state aid to the
University following Federal
District Court Judge Joseph H.
Young's ruling that Hopkins and
other non-parochial private
institutions need not consider
themselves defendants in a suit
filed last summer by the
American Civil Liberties Union
(ACLU).
The program which provides
the state funding was passed in
1971 by the Maryland State
General Assembly and is
presently being challenged on the
grounds that it violates the
constitutional principle of
separation of church and state.
Several area parochial colleges,
including Notre Dame and
Loyola, must await the final
disposition of the suit before
receiving their funds.
Ellery Woodwsorth, Special
Assistant to President Muller for
legislative affairs, maintains that
Judge Young's final decision on
the constitutionality of the
Program will not affect Hopkins'
future funding status.

Shei,,

"When the law was enacted,"
said Woodworth,"we included in
the statute a separability clause
which said that if funds for one
of the parties were declared
unconstitutional, it would not
hold true for all others."
The program makes state
financial aid available to all
private institutions in the state
according to the number of
Associate and Bachelor or Arts
degrees awarded each acacemic
year to Maryland resident
students.
According to Woodworth, this
year's allocation exceeded that of
1972 by approximately $35,000.
The difference, he commented, is
due chiefly to the institution of
an Associate of the Arts Degree
program in theEvening College.
The new degree enables the
University to receive, in addition
to $1000 per Bachelor of the Arts
or Engineering Sciences degree,
$200 per Associate degree
conferred.
Registrar's records show that
354 Bachelor's and 14 Associate
degrees were earned by Maryland
resident Hopkins studnets during
the 1971-72 academic year.

SAIS head Wilcox announces resignation
By PETER GARDNER
Francis 0. Wilcox, Dean of the
University's School of Advanced
International Studies (SAIS), will
retire effective September 1, 1973.
In recognition of his
distinguised service to Johns
Hopkins and SAIS, the
University's Trustees have
appointed Wilcox Dean Emeritus
of the School. The appointment
becomes effective the date of his
retirement.
Dean Wilcox, who will turn 65
this year, must retire from his
administrative position in
accordance with University
policy. He will, however,
continue to serve the school and
the University 'as- a part-time
consultant.

Dr. Wilcox, who currently
holds a professorship in the fields
of international organization and
American foreign policy, has
headed this Washington- based
graduate division of the
University since 1961. Prior to this
he served for teri years as the
chief of staff for the U.S. Senate
Foreign Relations Committee,
and from 1955 to 1961 he was the
Assistant Secretary of the State
for International Organization
Affairs.
In addition to announcing the
Dean's retirement, University
President Steven Muller
commented upon Wilcox's
service to the University. "Dean
Wilcox has guided the School of
Advanced International Studies

through a period of rapid and
important change in international
relations," Muller remarked.
"His success in building a
meaningful program in
international studies and in
pointing its content toward
future needs in the international
field during period has been a
remarkable achievement. We face
a difficult challenge in finding his
successor."
Among the major innovations
effected during Dean Wilcox's
tenure was the establishment of
the Center of Candian Studies,
the only graduate and research
center in the United States
concentrating on Canada.
Additionally, the School nearly
tripled the size of its student

body and its faculty greatly
expanded its •course offerings,
developed an impressive doctoral
program and built eight story
facility on Massachusetts Avenue
in Washington.
Dr. Harry Woolf, University
Provost, will chair the Search
Committee for the new Dean.
Accordint to Woolf, the selestion
of committee members was
completed Tuesday and "now we
will begin the search following
normal procedures," he said.
"The Committee is here as a
body of first judgement," he
remarked," and we will proceed
with a standard sifting process by
which we will end up with a
certain number of candidates."

Blue Jay Basketballers Fly High in Florida
By MIKE LaTAPE
Since defeating UMBC to gain
fifth place in the Schaefer Metro
Tournament, the Blue Jay
basketball team has garnered an
8-5 overall record and a 4-1
record in the MAC conference.
The Thursday following the
tournament, the Jays traveled to
Washington to battle the
Cardinals of Catholic University.
At the end of the first half, the
Jays led 40-34, thanks to the
shooting of Bob Freedman, Paul
Spence, and Bill Jews and the
defensive work of .John Rutter
and Chuck LaBerge.
But fouls began to take their
toll on the Blue Jay starters.
Player after player was forced'out
of the contest, allowing Catholic
to tie the score at 86 just before
regulation time ran out.
With Rutter, Freedman, Jews
and LaBerge all out on fouls,
Coach Gary Rupert was forced to
go with inexperienced people.
They were unable to stick with
Catholic starters in the overtime.
A close look at the final score
of 102-96 yields some interesting
insights into the game. Hopkins
scored 7 more field goals than
the Cardinals,, but finished a
poor second at the charity stripe
The Jays converted 16 of 21 while
Catholic cashed in on 36 of 55,
outscoring the Jays by 20.
In their, next outing, the Blue
Jays ran a mediocre Swarthmore
team out of the Athletic Center.
Freedman, Jews,Spence, and
Greg DeLong all hit for double
figures while Jews and DeLong
garnered 17 and 12 rebounds
respectively
The Little Quakers were no
match for an obviously superior
Hopkins quintet. Guards Rutter
and Freedman forced many
turnovers with their harassment.
Coupled with the strong
rebounding, Hopkins was able to
score an easy victory without
playing top notch basketball.
After the Christmas break, the
team drove to Florida to
participate in the Eckerd College
Invitational Tournament. Also
participating in the tournament
were Alma College of Michigan
and King College of Bristol,
Tennessee.
On the first eventing, the Blue
Jays faced host Eckerd. Eckerd
had been playing regularly since
late November and had compiled
a record of 8-1. Conversely,
Hopkins had practiced only twice
since the Swarthmore game. The
Jays had not recovered from the
long drive either.
Although not the sole cause.
for their sloppy play, the trip did
contribute to the 95-81 defeat.
The key to the Eckerd victory
was balance and conditioning. All
seven of the Eckerd players that
entered --: the game scored in
double figures. Only Jews (37)
and Freedman (20) broke that
barrier for Hopkin . Jews also
pulled down 20 rebounds. Thes&
two figures broke the existing,
records for the Eckered gym.
The superior conditioning of.
the Tritons became evident eaily
in the second half. As the Bluel
Jays tired, they began to foul
more. and more. At the end of
the contest, three of the five;
starters,had fouled out.

It was much the same story
the next evening as the Blue Jays
bowed to Alma College. The
Scots rolled to a 53-39 half-time
led by outhustling the weary
Jays. Time after time, Alma
simply outran the Blue Jays and
scored uncontested shots.
In the second half, Hopkins
began to close the margin, but
fouls prevented them from
getting any closer than eight. The
second half surge was led by Greg
DeLong who hit for 14 of his 18
points in the second half. Jews
again led Hopkins scorers with 20
while LaBerge, Spence, and
Freedman again scored in double
figures.
For the tournament, the Blue
Jays finished fourth with Bill
Jews being named to the
All-Tournament team (both on
and off the court). Hopkins was
the only visiting team not to fly
to Florida. The weariness of the
players contributed to the subpar
performances at the tournament.
But all was not lost in Florida.
After the Eckerd game, the team
'drove (or flew, depending on
who you were driving with)
across Alligator Alley, arriving in
Ft. Lauderdale on Sunday
morning. Sunday was a day of
sun and fun on the beach.
On Monday, the Jays defeated
a big strong Ft. Lauderdale
outfit. As usual, Rutter and
Freedman controlled the flow
the the game, allowing the Jays
to play just hard enough to win.
Spence, Jews, Freedman,
DeLong, and LaBerge all hit for
double figures. Spence also had
10 assists while the big men
controlled the boards.
After traveling back up the
coast, the Jays attempted to
recuperate from the trip before_
facing powerful Widener
(formerly PMC) in Chester.
Hopkins stuck with the Pioneers
for the first ten minutes,but
scored only four points in the
remaining time before
intermission. The 39-20 halftime
lead proved too much for the
Blue Jays to overcome as
Widener coasted to a 74-55 win.
Freedman and Spence were the
only Jays to score in double
figures. The Widener game is best
forgotten.

The team's next opponent was
Moravian--a rather easy MAC foe.
The outcome was never in doubt
as the Jays turned it on when
they had to but they made it
look close. John Rutter, playing
with injured knees, was the
sparkplug while Bill Jews was the
piston in the machine. Rutter
finished with 9 points and 8
assists while Jews poured in 31
and Freedman 12. There was no
doubt as to which was the
superior team.
Three days later, Hopkins
traveled to Westminster to battle
old nemesis Western Maryland.
The Terrors are especially tough
playing in that "outhouse" they
call a gym, but the Jays were
ready. Playing a scrambling,
revc lying team defense, Hopkins
corecd turnover after turnover to
tally annihilate Western
Mat,89-66.

mobile substitute Andy "Oscar"
Schreiber who scored several key
baskets in the contest, and used

out hustle his defender. He

After playing 10 of their first 11

Since defeating UMBC to gain

defensive work of .John Rutter
and Chuck LaBerge.

toll on the Blue Jay starters.
Player after player was forced'out
of the contest, allowing Catholic
to tie the score at 86 just before
regulation time ran out.
With Rutter, Freedman, Jews
and LaBerge all out on fouls,
Coach Gary Rupert was forced to
go with inexperienced people.
They were unable to stick with
Catholic starters in the overtime.
A close look at the final score
of 102-96 yields some interesting
insights into the game. Hopkins
scored 7 more field goals than
the Cardinals,, but finished a
poor second at the charity stripe

Catholic cashed in on 36 of 55,
outscoring the Jays by 20.

Jays ran a mediocre Swarthmore
team out of the Athletic Center.

figures while Jews and DeLong
garnered 17 and 12 rebounds
respectively

match for an obviously superior
Hopkins quintet. Guards Rutter
and Freedman forced many
turnovers with their harassment.

rebounding, Hopkins was able to
score an easy victory without
playing top notch basketball.

team drove to Florida to
participate in the Eckerd College
Invitational Tournament. Also
participating in the tournament
were Alma College of Michigan
and King College of Bristol,
Tennessee.

Jays faced host Eckerd. Eckerd
had been playing regularly since
late November and had compiled
a record of 8-1. Conversely,
Hopkins had practiced only twice
since the Swarthmore game. The
Jays had not recovered from the
long drive either.
Although not the sole cause.
for their sloppy play, the trip did
contribute to the 95-81 defeat.
The key to the Eckerd victory
was balance and conditioning. All
seven of the Eckerd players that
entered --: the game scored in
double figures. Only Jews (37)
and Freedman (20) broke that
barrier for Hopkin . Jews also
pulled down 20 rebounds. Thes&
two figures broke the existing,
records for the Eckered gym.
The superior conditioning of.
the Tritons became evident eaily
in the second half. As the Bluel
Jays tired, they began to foul
more. and more. At the end of
the contest, three of the five;
starters,had fouled out.

It was much the same story
the next evening as the Blue Jays
bowed to Alma College. The
Scots rolled to a 53-39 half-time
led by outhustling the weary
Jays. Time after time, Alma
simply outran the Blue Jays and
scored uncontested shots.
In the second half, Hopkins
began to close the margin, but
fouls prevented them from
getting any closer than eight. The
second half surge was led by Greg
DeLong who hit for 14 of his 18
points in the second half. Jews
again led Hopkins scorers with 20
while LaBerge, Spence, and
Freedman again scored in double
figures.

Jays finished fourth with Bill
Jews being named to the
All-Tournament team (both on
and off the court). Hopkins was
the only visiting team not to fly
to Florida. The weariness of the
players contributed to the subpar
performances at the tournament.

After the Eckerd game, the team
'drove (or flew, depending on
who you were driving with)
across Alligator Alley, arriving in
Ft. Lauderdale on Sunday
morning. Sunday was a day of
sun and fun on the beach.

a big strong Ft. Lauderdale
outfit. As usual, Rutter and
Freedman controlled the flow
the the game, allowing the Jays
to play just hard enough to win.

double figures. Spence also had
10 assists while the big men
controlled the boards.

coast, the Jays attempted to
recuperate from the trip before_
facing powerful Widener

remaining time before
intermission. The 39-20 halftime
lead proved too much for the

only Jays to score in double
figures. The Widener game is best
forgotten.

Moravian--a rather easy MAC foe.

look close. John Rutter, playing

sparkplug while Bill Jews was the
piston in the machine. Rutter
finished with 9 points and 8
assists while Jews poured in 31
and Freedman 12. There was no
doubt as to which was the
superior team.

traveled to Westminster to battle
old nemesis Western Maryland.

ready. Playing a scrambling,

out hustle his defender. He

29, with Freedman, LaBerge, and

figures.

Jays returned to the friendly
confines of the Athletic Center
for a game with theGettysburg•
Bullets. Again the Jays played
just well enough to
win--defeating the taller Bullets
by a score of 77-72. The victory

two starting guards, Rutter and

figures were Spence (12),

chipped in eight points.

Last Saturday Havergord traveled
to the Athletic Centr to test the
high-flying Jays. They should
have stayed in Pennsylvania.

triumph. The victory broke the
school and gym records for most
points scored in a game and was
also the largest margin of victory
by which a Hopkins team had
ever defeated an opponent. Each

player unselfishly gave the ball
up to the open man, as the ghing

per formances.

8-5 (4-1 in MAC play) with 11
games remaining (6 in the MAC).

records for most wins in a season

(11) and best season record (10-7).

83.5 points per game, the Jays

Athletic- Center tomorrow night.

Youth Corps project sought to clean up Wyman Park
By MARTIN FRENCH .
The Greater Homewood
Community Corporation is filing
an application today for a
Neighborhood Youth Corps
project in Wyman Park.
In an executive meeting of
the CHCC Board of Directors on
January 17 the project goals
defined by the Wyman Park
Advisory Committee were
approved for the GHGC
application. Project goals include
cleaning the trash and debris
from Stony Run and from the
hillsides of Wyman Park,
removing weeds and underbrush
from the park, filling in land for
eroded areas and new pathways
in the park, and painting and
carving signs and markers to be
placed in the park. The Advisory
Committee set as an optional
goal construction of a footbridge
over Stony Run. The project
proposal must be approved by
the City of Baltimore which
disburses the Federal funds
provided for the summertime
employment of high-schoolers
aged 14 to 21.
"This year Mayor Schaefer
wants neighborhood-oriented
projects for NYC workers,"
stated Dick Cook, Executive
Director of GHCC. "Last year he
wanted that too, but the damage
due to tropical storm Agnes
forced the use of NYC workers in
clean-up work.v In addition to
being neighborhood- conceived,
these projects are to be
neighborhood-directed, which
required that GHCC find money
to pay for a project supervisor.
"The NYC program requires
one supervisor for every ten
enrollees," Cook explained,"and
we are hoping to get two
supervisors and about twenty
-five NYC workers for this park
project. One supervisor will be
paid by GHCC, the other by
member neighborhood
associations, including the
Wyman Park Improvement
Association." All of these
organizations receive funding

•

from members and sponsors but
ahve not budgeted for this
project in advance.
This year NYC workers may
be hired for projects which are to
be in their own neighborhoods.
"This is a GHCC goal, for we
want to increase area interest in
Wyman Park as well as give the
youth something constructive to
do," said Randolph Chalfant, a
member of the Wyman Park
Advisory Committee. "Just
having them work on their own
park is a really fine idea, and we
hope their friends and parents
will take notice," he added.
Since NYC enrollees must be
in high school and from
low-income families, only some
of the Greater Homewood area
youth will be eligible for the
Wyman Park project.
The goals adopted for this
project are included in a report in
Wyman Park prepared by seven
Hopkins students under the
guidance of Dave BockIke, a
graduate instructor in the
Department of Geography and
Environmental Engineering.
The Wyman Park report also
contains proposals for nature
trails and a bicycle path now
being studies by the Advisory
Committee.

provisions of the bills from

private constituents helped to
